title: Gazza said he sounded slurred on train because he’d removed his false teeth
text:
Former England footballer Paul Gascoigne arrives for his trial at Teesside Crown Court this morning (Picture: PA)

Paul Gascoigne was accused of ‘lying through his teeth’ when he said he only sounded slurred when he kissed a woman on a train because he had removed a dental bridge.

The former footballer, 52, denies sexually assaulting a woman on a York to Newcastle train in August 2018.

He claims he only kissed the complainant ‘to reassure her after overhearing someone call her fat’.

In his closing speech to the jury, prosecutor William Mousley QC said: Right from the start, members of the jury, [Gascoigne] lied and lied and lied.

‘He lied right up to and including the time when he was giving evidence in court yesterday.

‘There’s an obvious reason as to why he lied and that’s because he knows he is guilty of sexual assault but wants to put up a smokescreen, cause a diversion, suggest it was not as it so obviously was.’

The former footballer denies sexual assault after kissing a woman on a train between York and Newcastle last year (Picture: Getty)

Defence lawyer Michelle Heeley QC, in her own closing speech, argued: ‘Quite frankly, the defence case is that you cannot be sure that Mr Gascoigne had a sexual intention.

‘In his own naive way, he thought he was making a larger woman have more body confidence.

‘It’s a clumsy way to go about building someone’s confidence, but it was not sexual.’

Jurors were told by Judge Peter Armstrong today that they will be offered a less serious charge of assault by beating if they clear Gascoigne of sexual assault.

Mr Mousley launched a scathing attack on Gascoigne’s account of the incident at Teesside Crown Court, insisting he had made it all up.

The prosecutor urged the jury to treat the football legend like anybody else as ‘he is not deserving of special treatment’.

Referencing Gascoigne’s suggestion that he wasn’t drunk but sounded slurred during the train journey because he had taken a bridge of false teeth out, the prosecutor said the football star had ‘lied through his teeth, whichever teeth they were’.

Gascoigne, pictured earlier this week, claims he only kissed the complainant ‘to reassure her after overhearing someone call her fat’ (Picture: Getty)

He said of the kiss: ‘Either it was an unpleasant assault, or it was an act of kindness. Guilty if the former, not guilty if it were the latter.

‘This is a case, we submit, about truth and lies. There is a stark difference between the two and we submit that if you approach this case by deciding which facts you are sure about, that will lead you to a conclusion one way or the other.’

Miss Heeley, defending, told jurors the former footballer kissed a woman who was not expecting it and did not like it, but that did not make him a sex offender.

She added: ‘A kiss could mean many things, including a celebration when you score one of the greatest goals England has ever seen, against Scotland in Euro 96.’

The trial continues.
